Legal_Issue: Whether Apotex must address AstraZeneca's '762 Patent under the NOC Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Timing of marketing post-NOC issuance, product specificity of the patent
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to demonstrate improper listing
Legal_Rule: Subsection 5(1) of the NOC Regulations requires generic manufacturers to address patents listed on the register if the drug was marketed in Canada pursuant to an NOC
Procedural_Issue: Challenge to the Minister's decision on patent listing
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper listing of the '762 Patent due to timing and product specificity
Key_Evidence_Considered: AstraZeneca's listing of the '762 Patent against multiple NOCs, marketing timeline
Legal_Framework: Regulatory framework for patent listing under NOC Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Apotex challenged the Minister's requirement to address the '762 Patent
Defendant_Response: Minister contended that marketing occurred post-NOC issuance, triggering regulatory obligations
Evidence_Type: Regulatory filings, patent register entries, NOC records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Minister's decision
Outcome: Apotex required to address the '762 Patent
